DataElement.preferredName: Metastatic And/Or Recurrent Malignant Neoplasm Tissue Sample Collection Method Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that describes the method of which metastatic/recurrent tumor/cancer tissue is removed from a patient.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Metastatic And/Or Recurrent Malignant Neoplasm Tissue Sample Collection Method
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site._Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid._The reemergence of a malignant neoplasm after a period of remission._A piece of tissue removed from an organism for examination, analysis, or propagation._The act of gathering things together; having been brought together in one place._A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Metastatic And/Or Recurrent Malignant Neoplasm Tissue Sample
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.:Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.:The reemergence of a malignant neoplasm after a period of remission.:A piece of tissue removed from an organism for examination, analysis, or propagation.

Concepts.definition: A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
The reemergence of a malignant neoplasm after a period of remission.
A piece of tissue removed from an organism for examination, analysis, or propagation.

Property.preferredDefinition: The act of gathering things together; having been brought together in one place.:A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

Concepts.definition: The act of gathering things together; having been brought together in one place.
A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Concepts linked to Tissue Banking and Pathology activities

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the type of procedure or method used to collect the specimen._Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products._The act of gathering something together.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Left; being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.: Surgical removal of approximately half of the colon.

Concepts.definition: Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.
Surgical removal of approximately half of the colon.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Right; being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.: Surgical removal of approximately half of the colon.

Concepts.definition: Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.
Surgical removal of approximately half of the colon.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Fluid withdrawn from a body cavity, organ, cyst, or tumor.

Concepts.definition: Fluid withdrawn from a body cavity, organ, cyst, or tumor.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated definition to current NCIt. 4.10.19 mc

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Be specific about something; define clearly.

Concepts.definition: Be specific about something; define clearly.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure in which part of a lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure in which part of a lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated system generated definition with current NCIt definition. mc 11/12/12

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure in which an entire lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure in which an entire lesion is removed for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition:
Surgery done using a laparoscope.
: Surgery to remove part of one kidney or a kidney tumor, but not an entire kidney.

Concepts.definition: Surgery done using a laparoscope.
The surgical removal of a portion of a kidney.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove part or all of an organ or a tumor and nearby lymph nodes. The incision is large enough to let the surgeon see into the body.: Surgery to remove part of one kidney or a kidney tumor, but not an entire kidney.

Concepts.definition: Surgery to remove part or all of an organ or a tumor and nearby lymph nodes. The incision is large enough to let the surgeon see into the body.
The surgical removal of a portion of a kidney.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of laparoscopic surgery where the surgeon uses both a laparoscope and his or her hand to help with dissection, retraction, and removal of tissue through a hand port incision.: Surgical removal of a kidney, the adrenal gland, adjacent lymph nodes, and other surrounding tissue.

Concepts.definition: A type of laparoscopic surgery where the surgeon uses both a laparoscope and his or her hand to help with dissection, retraction, and removal of tissue through a hand port incision.
Surgical removal of a kidney, the adrenal gland, adjacent lymph nodes, and other surrounding tissue.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Added concepts per request by TCGA. mc 11/12/12

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition:
Surgery done using a laparoscope.
: Surgical removal of a kidney, the adrenal gland, adjacent lymph nodes, and other surrounding tissue.

Concepts.definition: Surgery done using a laparoscope.
Surgical removal of a kidney, the adrenal gland, adjacent lymph nodes, and other surrounding tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove part or all of an organ or a tumor and nearby lymph nodes. The incision is large enough to let the surgeon see into the body.: Surgical removal of a kidney, the adrenal gland, adjacent lymph nodes, and other surrounding tissue.

Concepts.definition: Surgery to remove part or all of an organ or a tumor and nearby lymph nodes. The incision is large enough to let the surgeon see into the body.
Surgical removal of a kidney, the adrenal gland, adjacent lymph nodes, and other surrounding tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 1/25/23 added alt name for ticket number CADSR0001948 for CCTG cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to the lumen or inner part of the rectum.: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to the lumen or inner part of the rectum.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Added concepts per request by TCGA. mc 11/12/12

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of the entire colon, anus, and rectum.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of the entire colon, anus, and rectum.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Added concept per TCGA request. mc 11/12/12

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A therapeutic surgical procedure in which the anus, rectum, part of the sigmoid colon, and the regional lymph nodes are removed through abdominal and perineal incisions.: The terminal portion of the gastrointestinal tract, extending from the rectosigmoid junction to the anal canal.

Concepts.definition: A therapeutic surgical procedure in which the anus, rectum, part of the sigmoid colon, and the regional lymph nodes are removed through abdominal and perineal incisions.
The terminal portion of the gastrointestinal tract, extending from the rectosigmoid junction to the anal canal.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Denoting the front surface of the body; often used to indicate the position of one structure relative to another.: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ. : The terminal portion of the gastrointestinal tract, extending from the rectosigmoid junction to the anal canal.

Concepts.definition: Denoting the front surface of the body; often used to indicate the position of one structure relative to another.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.
The terminal portion of the gastrointestinal tract, extending from the rectosigmoid junction to the anal canal.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of the entire colon.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of the entire colon.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The portion of the colon that connects to the descending colon above and the rectum below.: Surgical removal of part or all of the colon.

Concepts.definition: The portion of the colon that connects to the descending colon above and the rectum below.
Surgical removal of part or all of the colon.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of the transverse colon.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of the transverse colon.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical creation of an opening of the skull.

Concepts.definition: Surgical creation of an opening of the skull.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of tissue or fluid with a thin needle for examination under a microscope.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue or fluid with a thin needle for examination under a microscope.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of tissue or fluid with a needle for examination under a microscope. When a wide needle is used, the procedure is called a core biopsy. When a thin needle is used, the procedure is called a fine-needle aspiration biopsy.

Concepts.definition: The removal of a tissue sample using a needle, for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Added OBIB alternate name and identifier DW -03-21-2019

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Mucous membrane.: A surgical procedure done with the use or assistance of an endoscopic device.: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: Mucous membrane.
A surgical procedure done with the use or assistance of an endoscopic device.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis. In the case of an endoscopic biopsy, an endoscope is used to obtain the sample.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis. In the case of an endoscopic biopsy, an endoscope is used to obtain the sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of a triangular wedge shaped section of tissue.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of a triangular wedge shaped section of tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery performed with a special instrument inserted through the urethra.

Concepts.definition: Surgery performed with a special instrument inserted through the urethra.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Healthy skin, bone, or other tissue taken from one part of the body and used to replace diseased or injured tissue removed from another part of the body.

Concepts.definition: Tissue or organ transplanted from a donor to a recipient.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A minimally invasive thoracic surgical procedure that makes use of a thoracoscope.: Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.

Concepts.definition: A minimally invasive thoracic surgical procedure that makes use of a thoracoscope.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Partial; being or affecting only a part; not total: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: Being or affecting only a part of something.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure involving the removal of the entire breast tissue, nipple and a portion of the overlying skin, while leaving the axillary contents intact.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure involving the removal of the entire breast tissue, nipple and a portion of the overlying skin, while leaving the axillary contents intact.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove all of one lung.

Concepts.definition: The excision of part or all of a lung.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of one or both testicles.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of one or both testicles.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of a lobe of an organ.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of a lobe of an organ.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not characterized in any other way.: A surgical procedure to remove the uterine body (partial hysterectomy) or the uterine body and cervix (total hysterectomy).

Concepts.definition: Not characterized in any other way.
A surgical procedure to remove the uterine body (partial hysterectomy) or the uterine body and cervix (total hysterectomy).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Visible to the naked eye.: The surgical removal of an entire structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: Visible to the naked eye.
Surgical removal of an entire lesion as confirmed by pathology. Surgical margins are clear.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure to remove the uterine body and cervix. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure to remove the uterine body and cervix. -- 2004

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure by which tissue or an organ (usually containing a tumor) is removed without rupture from a specific anatomic site.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure by which tissue or an organ (usually containing a tumor) is removed without rupture from a specific anatomic site.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove all or part of the bladder (the organ that holds urine) or to remove a cyst (a sac or capsule in the body).

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of the urinary bladder; or the surgical removal of a cyst..

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Added OBIB alternate name and identifier - DW 03-21-2019

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Aspiration of immature hematopoietic elements and blood from the bone marrow.  It is done for the evaluation of hematopoietic disorders and for the evaluation of infectious diseases and cytogenetic studies.

Concepts.definition: Aspiration of immature hematopoietic elements and blood from the bone marrow.  It is done for the evaluation of hematopoietic disorders and for the evaluation of infectious diseases and cytogenetic studies.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The puncture of a vein with a needle for the purpose of drawing blood.

Concepts.definition: The collection of blood from a vein, most commonly via needle venipuncture.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery done using a laparoscope.: Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.

Concepts.definition: Surgery done using a laparoscope.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove abnormal tissue or cancer from the breast and a small amount of normal tissue around it. It is a type of breast-sparing surgery.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of a discrete mass.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery for breast cancer in which the breast, most or all of the lymph nodes under the arm, and the lining over the chest muscles are removed. Sometimes the surgeon also removes part of the chest wall muscles.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of one or both breasts, including the areola, nipple, and the majority of the axillary lymph nodes, but sparing the pectoralis major muscle.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Removal of only the breast tissue and nipple and a small portion of the overlying skin.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure involving the removal of the entire breast tissue, nipple and a portion of the overlying skin, while leaving the axillary contents intact.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical technique that uses a specially designed robotic system to aid with a laparoscopic surgical procedure.: Surgery to remove the entire prostate. The two types of radical prostatectomy are retropubic prostatectomy (surgery through an incision in the wall of the abdomen) and perineal prostatectomy (surgery through an incision between the scrotum and the anus).

Concepts.definition: A surgical technique that uses a specially designed robotic system to aid with a laparoscopic surgical procedure.
The surgical removal of all of the prostate as well as some surrounding tissue, including lymph nodes.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Laparoscopic Surgery Without Robot-Assisted Laparoscopic Surgery Radical Prostatectomy

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Laparoscopic Surgery Without Robot-Assisted Laparoscopic Surgery Radical Prostatectomy
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery done using a laparoscope.: Used to indicate the absence or lack of something or someone.: A surgical technique that uses a specially designed robotic system to aid with a laparoscopic surgical procedure.: Surgery to remove the entire prostate. The two types of radical prostatectomy are retropubic prostatectomy (surgery through an incision in the wall of the abdomen) and perineal prostatectomy (surgery through an incision between the scrotum and the anus).

Concepts.definition: Surgery done using a laparoscope.
Used to indicate the absence or lack of something or someone.
A surgical technique that uses a specially designed robotic system to aid with a laparoscopic surgical procedure.
The surgical removal of all of the prostate as well as some surrounding tissue, including lymph nodes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove part or all of an organ or a tumor and nearby lymph nodes. The incision is large enough to let the surgeon see into the body.: Surgery to remove the entire prostate. The two types of radical prostatectomy are retropubic prostatectomy (surgery through an incision in the wall of the abdomen) and perineal prostatectomy (surgery through an incision between the scrotum and the anus).

Concepts.definition: Surgery to remove part or all of an organ or a tumor and nearby lymph nodes. The incision is large enough to let the surgeon see into the body.
The surgical removal of all of the prostate as well as some surrounding tissue, including lymph nodes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree, intensity or amount.: Denoting the front surface of the body; often used to indicate the position of one structure relative to another.: The part of the large intestine measured from the cecum to the rectum consisting of ascending, transverse, descending and sigmoid portions. The purpose of the colon is to remove water from digested food prior to excretion.: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree, intensity or amount.
Denoting the front surface of the body; often used to indicate the position of one structure relative to another.

The part of the large intestine measured from the cecum to the rectum consisting of ascending, transverse, descending and sigmoid portions. The purpose of the colon is to remove water from digested food prior to excretion.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: To a complete degree or to the full or entire extent.: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

Concepts.definition: To a complete degree or to the full or entire extent.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Situated farthest from a point of attachment or origin, as of a limb or bone; or directed away from the midline of the body.: Surgical removal of part of the pancreas.

Concepts.definition: Situated farthest from a point of attachment or origin, as of a limb or bone; or directed away from the midline of the body.
Surgical removal of part of the pancreas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of part of the pancreas, duodenum, and distal part of the bile duct.  Sometimes, the lower portion of the stomach and the gallbladder are also removed.  This procedure is performed for pancreatic, ampullary, duodenal and distal bile duct cancers.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of part of the pancreas, duodenum, and distal part of the bile duct.  Sometimes, the lower portion of the stomach and the gallbladder are also removed.  This procedure is performed for pancreatic, ampullary, duodenal and distal bile duct cancers.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Insertion of a thin needle or tube into the abdomen to remove fluid from the peritoneal cavity.

Concepts.definition: The removal of excess fluid via needle puncture from any body cavity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Procedures for the collection and/or preparation of biological specimens for light microscopy examination.

Concepts.definition: Procedures for the collection and/or preparation of biological specimens for light microscopy examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The systematic withdrawal of fluids and discharges from a wound, sore or cavity.

Concepts.definition: The systematic withdrawal of fluids and discharges from a wound, sore or cavity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A therapeutic endoscopic procedure performed to remove adenomas from the ampulla of Vater. It involves the excision of the ampulla of Vater and the implantation of the common bile duct and pancreatic main duct into the wall of duodenum.

Concepts.definition: A therapeutic endoscopic procedure performed to remove adenomas from the ampulla of Vater. It involves the excision of the ampulla of Vater and the implantation of the common bile duct and pancreatic main duct into the wall of duodenum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cystic dilatation of the hepatic duct or bile duct.: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: Cystic dilatation of the hepatic duct or bile duct.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any of the ducts conveying bile between the liver and the intestine, including hepatic, cystic, and common bile duct.: Resection of a segment of an organ or partial resection of a gland.

Concepts.definition: Any of the ducts conveying bile between the liver and the intestine, including hepatic, cystic, and common bile duct.
Resection of a segment of an organ or partial resection of a gland.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of or pertaining to the pancreas.: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: Of or pertaining to the pancreas.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Refers to the area associated with the hilum.: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: Refers to the area associated with the hilum.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of the entire liver.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of the entire liver.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lesser or smaller in amount, extent, or size.: Partial removal of the liver

Concepts.definition: Lesser or smaller in amount, extent, or size.
Partial removal of the liver

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Greater or bigger in amount, extent, or size.: Partial removal of the liver

Concepts.definition: Greater or bigger in amount, extent, or size.
Partial removal of the liver

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove one or more metastases (tumors formed from cells that have spread from the primary tumor). When all metastases are removed, it is called a complete metastasectomy.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of metastases.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Removal of a disk of skin tissue, for microscopic examination, using a punch.

Concepts.definition: Removal of a disk of skin tissue, for microscopic examination, using a punch.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A lymph node that drains lymph from a region of interest.: Surgical excision of one or more lymph nodes. Its most common use is in cancer surgery. (From Dorland, 28th ed, p966)

Concepts.definition: A lymph node that drains lymph from a region of interest.
Surgical removal of lymph nodes, usually done to assess the spread of cancer.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of the right fallopian tube and right ovary.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of the right fallopian tube and right ovary.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove both fallopian tubes, as well as both ovaries.

Concepts.definition: Surgery to remove both fallopian tubes, as well as both ovaries.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A hysterectomy that removes the uterus and leaves the cervix in place.

Concepts.definition: A hysterectomy that removes the uterus and leaves the cervix in place.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure to remove the uterine body and cervix. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure to remove the uterine body and cervix. -- 2004

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove the uterus, cervix, and part of the vagina. The ovaries, fallopian tubes, and nearby lymph nodes may also be removed.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of the uterus and surrounding structures, including bilateral pelvic lymph nodes, the parametrium, and the upper one-third to one-half of the vagina.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Total Abdominal Hysterectomy with Bilateral Salpingo-Oophorectomy

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Total Abdominal Hysterectomy with Bilateral Salpingo-Oophorectomy
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of all of the uterus, and the right and left fallopian tubes, and the right and left ovaries.

Concepts.longName: Total Abdominal Hysterectomy with Bilateral Salpingo-Oophorectomy
Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of all of the uterus, and the right and left fallopian tubes, and the right and left ovaries.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The systematic withdrawal of ascitic fluid  from the abdominal cavity.

Concepts.definition: The systematic withdrawal of ascitic fluid  from the abdominal cavity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of excess fluid via needle puncture from the thoracic cavity.

Concepts.definition: The removal of excess fluid via needle puncture from the thoracic cavity.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated definition to match current NCIt. mc 4.23.19

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The surgical removal of one or both ovaries.

Concepts.definition: Partial or complete removal of one or both of the ovaries.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A physical quality in which the entity or structure is broken into pieces.: Surgery to remove all or part of the bladder (the organ that holds urine) or to remove a cyst (a sac or capsule in the body).

Concepts.definition: A physical quality in which the entity or structure is broken into pieces.
The surgical removal of the urinary bladder; or the surgical removal of a cyst..

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A minimally invasive procedure that permits sampling of peritoneal fluid for cytopathologic analysis.

Concepts.definition: A minimally invasive procedure that permits sampling of peritoneal fluid for cytopathologic analysis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The tissue that lines the wall of the abdominal cavity, intestine, and mesentery. It consists of the parietal peritoneum that covers the inside of the abdominal wall and the visceral peritoneum that covers the surface of the intestine and mesentery.: Surgical removal of as much of a tumor as possible. Tumor debulking may increase the chance that chemotherapy or radiation therapy will kill all the tumor cells. It may also be done to relieve symptoms or help the patient live longer.

Concepts.definition: The tissue that lines the wall of the abdominal cavity, intestine, mesentery, and pelvic organs. It consists of the parietal peritoneum and the visceral peritoneum.
The surgical removal of as much of a malignant tumor as is reasonably possible. This procedure increases the effectiveness of the subsequent administration of chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Removal of tissue from the peritoneum for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: Removal of tissue from the peritoneum for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Partial or complete resection of the omentum.

Concepts.definition: Partial or complete resection of the omentum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove part or all of the left fallopian tube.

Concepts.definition: Surgery to remove part or all of the left fallopian tube.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove part or all of the right fallopian tube.

Concepts.definition: Surgery to remove part or all of the right fallopian tube.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove part or all of both fallopian tubes.

Concepts.definition: Surgery to remove part or all of both fallopian tubes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of the fallopian tube(s) and ovary(ies).

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of the fallopian tube(s) and ovary(ies).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove part or all of the fallopian tube(s).

Concepts.definition: Surgery to remove part or all of the fallopian tube(s).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of the left fallopian tube and left ovary.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of the left fallopian tube and left ovary.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Be specific about something; define clearly.: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Be specific about something; define clearly.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The mucosal membranes located on the inside of the cheek, in the buccal cavity._The surgical removal of an organ or a part of an organ.

Concepts.definition: The mucosal membranes located on the inside of the cheek, in the buccal cavity.
The surgical removal of an organ or a part of an organ.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of major salivary glands located below the floor of the mouth._The surgical removal of an organ or a part of an organ.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Add as part of something else; put in as part of a set, group, or category.: To a complete degree or to the full or entire extent.: A surgical procedure by which tissue or an organ (usually containing a tumor) is removed without rupture from a specific anatomic site.: Surgery to remove tissue from the prostate using an instrument inserted through the urethra.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical excision of one or more lymph nodes. Its most common use is in cancer surgery. (From Dorland, 28th ed, p966)

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of lymph nodes, usually done to assess the spread of cancer.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove the entire prostate. The two types of radical prostatectomy are retropubic prostatectomy and perineal prostatectomy.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of all of the prostate as well as some surrounding tissue, including lymph nodes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical treatment undertaken after failure of initial surgery or failure of other modalities.: Surgical removal of lymph nodes, usually done to assess the spread of cancer.

Surgical removal of lymph nodes, usually done to assess the spread of cancer.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical treatment undertaken after failure of initial surgery or failure of other modalities.: Surgery to remove the entire prostate. The two types of radical prostatectomy are retropubic prostatectomy (surgery through an incision in the wall of the abdomen) and perineal prostatectomy (surgery through an incision between the scrotum and the anus).

Concepts.definition: Surgical treatment undertaken after failure of initial surgery or failure of other modalities.
The surgical removal of all of the prostate as well as some surrounding tissue, including lymph nodes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.: A drug or other substance that causes a loss of feeling or awareness. Local anesthetics cause a loss of feeling in one small area of the body. Regional anesthetics cause a loss of feeling in a part of the body, such as an arm or leg. General anesthetics cause a loss of feeling and a complete loss of awareness that feels like a very deep sleep.: A minimally invasive thoracic surgical procedure that makes use of a thoracoscope.: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

Concepts.definition: Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.
A pharmacological agent that acts in a reversible fashion and can be applied either locally or systemically to cause a partial or total loss of sensation and pain or to induce unconsciousness.
A minimally invasive thoracic surgical procedure that makes use of a thoracoscope.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.:The act of gathering something together.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.
The act of gathering things together; having been brought together in one place.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
